links.title: Amazon Ion
links.description: Amazon Ion is a richly-typed, self-describing, hierarchical data serialization format offering interchangeable binary and text representations. Ion was built to address rapid development, decoupling, and efficiency challenges faced every day while engineering large-scale, service-oriented architectures. Ion has been addressing these challenges within Amazon for nearly a decade, and we believe others will benefit as well.
links.original_title: Amazon Ion – a richly-typed, self-describing, hierarchical serialization format

links.title: Decentralized Identifiers (DIDs) v1.0
links.description:
Decentralized identifiers (DIDs) are a new type of identifier that
enables verifiable, decentralized digital identity. A DID refers to any
subject (e.g., a person, organization, thing, data model, abstract entity, etc.)
as determined by the controller of the DID. In contrast to
typical, federated identifiers, DIDs have been designed so that they may
be decoupled from centralized registries, identity providers, and certificate
authorities. Specifi...

links.title: Cap'n Proto: Schema Language
links.description:
Like Protocol Buffers and Thrift (but unlike JSON or MessagePack), Capân Proto messages are
strongly-typed and not self-describing. You must define your message structure in a special
language, then invoke the Capân Proto compiler (capnp compile) to generate source code to
manipulate that message type in your desired language.

links.title: basE91 - binary to ASCII text encoding
links.description: basE91 is an advanced method for encoding binary data as ASCII characters. It is similar to UUencode or base64, but is more efficient. The overhead produced by basE91 depends on the input data. It amounts at most to 23% (versus 33% for base64) and can range down to 14%, which typically occurs on 0-byte blocks. This makes basE91 very useful for transferring larger files over binary unsafe connections like e-mail or terminal lines.
